meaningMnemonic:
<kanji>Grief</kanji> shows in your <kanji>eye</kanji>s by making them look like you've gone through a lot of <vocabulary>bitterness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hardship</vocabulary>. You can always see it in someone else if you look them in the eyes too.

You’ll see this word most often in 憂き目を見る and 憂き目に合う, which both mean “to experience <vocabulary>misery</vocabulary>.”
readingMnemonic:
This word uses one of the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You haven’t learned this kun’yomi reading for 憂, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Why the <vocabulary>bitterness</vocabulary> in your eyes? You visited a famed <reading>u</reading>ni (う) restaurant, only to find it closed and locked. Where is the <reading>key</reading> (き)? Your <reading>目</reading>s scream of the uni missed. In a sea of <vocabulary>misery</vocabulary>, a missed uni is the hardest to swallow.
